metadata.title: One-Dimensional Nanomaterials for Soft Electronics

sections.text:
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (1 of 29) 1600314wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev iew One-Dimensional Nanomaterials for Soft Electronics Shu Gong and Wenlong Cheng*
DOI: 10.1002/aelm.201600314

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Electronic devices will evolve from the current rigid systems to flexible systems and ultimately to stretchable electronics, enabling true seamless integration of electronics with biology. The current wearable electronics may be the transition stage to such future electronic system. The development of soft wearable electronic systems for measurement and collection of biometric data provides a plethora of opportunities for artificial intelligence, disease diagnosis, sports tracking, and health monitoring.[1–7] It is encouraging to see a growing number of publications in this exciting area with ≈1400 publications in 2015; this is almost four times the number of publications 5 years ago. Various active materials have been used in soft wearable
Electronics will evolve from current rigid electronics to flexible electronics to ultimate soft stretchable electronics. The currently available, rapidly evolving wearable electronics may be a transitional stage to the future stretchable electronics. One-dimensional (1D) nanomaterials are being extensively used for the design of novel wearable conductors, sensors, and energy devices because 1D nanostructures have an intrinsically high-aspect-ratio that enables the construction of conductive percolation network with small amount of material usage while maintaining high optoelectronic performance. Simultaneously, 1D nanostructures have better mechanical elasticity than corresponding bulk materials or sphere-like nanoparticles and this is a key requirement for designing electronic skin materials by circumventing material delamination and/or cracking. Here, recent progress in 1D nanomaterials based on carbon, metal, metal oxides, polymer, and their hybrid structures is reviewed, focusing on the application of soft wearable electronics. In particular, 1D nanomaterial-based stretchable conductors, wearable pressure and strain sensors, wearable energy storage devices, and stretchable light-emitting diode devices are discussed in detail. Representative fabrication methodologies are described and their advantages/disadvantages are compared. Finally, the innovative application of 1D nanomaterial-based sensors/devices in health and wellness, safety, artificial intelligence, entertainment, and early detection of mental disorders is discussed.
S. Gong, Prof. W. L. Cheng Department of Chemical Engineering Monash University Clayton, Victoria 3800, Australia E-mail: wenlong.cheng@monash.edu S. Gong, Prof. W. L. Cheng The Melbourne Centre for Nanofabrication Clayton, Victoria 3800, Australia
electronics including conductive polymer thin films and indium tin oxide. Among these materials, 1D nanomaterials offer unique advantages due to their inherent high-aspect-ratio structural feature in conjunction with superior mechanical, electrical, and optical properties, which enables the construction of a high-performance percolation network for electronic skins (e-skin) with low consumption of materials yet high stretchability.[8,9]
1D nanomaterials in the context of this review refer to optically and/or electrically active nanostructures with widths between 1 and 100 nm.[10] Recently, several excellent review papers have covered recent achievements in flexible electronics from different perspectives.[1–9] However, a dedicated review on 1D nanomaterial-based soft wearable electronics has not been seen despite their potential and rapid progress. To fill this gap, we provide a detailed overview of the recent progress in soft wearable systems based on 1D nanomaterials. The advantages and contributions of 1D nanomaterials to wearable electronics are highlighted. Representative 1D nanomaterials (i.e., carbon nanotubes, metals
or metal oxides nanowires, polymer nanowires or nanofibers, and hybrid materials) are discussed in terms of their properties and fabrication strategies for the purpose of soft wearable electronics including stretchable conductors, sensors, energy devices, and light-emitting devices (LEDs). These 1D nanomaterials offer unique advantageous properties such as high transparency, high sensitivity, light weight, extreme thinness, low cost, and potential for large area fabrication.We also discuss the exciting applications of 1D nanomaterial-based wearable electronics in healthcare monitoring (i.e., heart beat rate), sport activity tracking (i.e., skin/muscle stretching), aged care monitoring (i.e., behavior monitoring), human-machine interfaces (i.e., wearable gaming), voice recognition (i.e., smart home), and heat management (i.e., thermal cloth). The outlook for 1D nanomaterial-based wearable electronics is provided at the end of the review.

sections.heading: 2. Why 1D Nanomaterials for Soft Electronics?
sections.text:
1D nanomaterials include carbon nanotubes, metallic nanowires, metal oxide nanowires, and conducting polymer nanowires. These have made significant contributions to the soft wearable electronic systems by improving optoelectronic
Adv. Electron. Mater. 2017, 1600314
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1600314 (2 of 29) wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev
ie w performance, expanding integration possibilities, and low-ering cost. This originates from their unique structural feature,
namely their high aspect ratio in conjunction with superior mechanical, electronic, and optical properties (Figure 1). This enables a balance between conductivity and stretchability, which is a key requirement in the design of e-skin materials, preventing material delamination and/or cracking under large mechanical strain.
Traditional electronics are based on rigid metal and semiconductor materials, resulting in current rigid circuitry boards that have outstanding optoelectronic properties but their mechanical compliance is poor. This sets insurmountable barriers for their integration with biological system due to inherent mechanical mismatch. Typically, metals have Young’s moduli >1000 times greater than that for human skin.[6] To achieve stretchable devices, two viable strategies have been used. One method is to deposit a metallic thin film onto a compliant substrate via printing, painting, sputtering, or other deposition strategies.[7] However, a serpentine design is usually required to prevent material delamination/cracking under large strain.[1] On the other hand, one could apply nanomaterials for designing intrinsically stretchable electronic devices. Compared to other nanomaterials, 1D nanomaterials have been proven to effectively lower the percolation threshold of conductive fillers.[11,12] According to the percolation theory[13,14] for random 1D nanomaterials sticks (or filaments), the length (L) of the conducting nanowires or nanotubes and the critical density (Nc) to maintain the conductive network for electron transport can be determined by:
5,71c 2N L = (1)
The conductivity (σ) of the network is given by:
cN N tσ ( )∝ − (2)
where N is the density of the conducting sticks. For a given density (N) of materials, the higher the aspect ratio is, the lower the critical density (Nc) is, and thus a higher conductivity can be achieved. This means the use of 1D nanomaterials could achieve a high conductivity with low usage of conductive materials. Furthermore, a 1D configuration provides high persistence length, which ensures a direct charge transport path and decreases the grain boundaries, compared with other configurations.[8] This is critical when a strain is applied as cracks or gaps may occur preferentially at the boundary area, which restrains the charge transport[15] and leads to large dependence of resistance on strain.[1]
Another attribute is that 1D nanomaterials are ideal for designing transparent conductors, which require high transparency and high conductivity simultaneously. However, high conductivity is a trade-off of high transparency. Typically, sphere-like nanomaterials are required to deposit beyond monolayer level to achieve high electrical conductivity, which lead to low optical transmittance preventing their applications in touch-on screens or light-emitting devices. This challenge can be overcome by 1D nanomaterials, such as metal nanowires and carbon nanotubes, which allow for the formation of 2D conducting percolation networks at the sub-monolayer level. The high conductivity
can be achieved via percolation junctions, whereas, the empty spaces between nanowires permit the high penetration of incident light. Hence, high conductivity and transparency can be achieved simultaneously. To date, a high transmittance of >90% and a low electrical resistance of ≈10 Ω sq−1 have been achieved based on metal nanowires,[16] which are comparable to indium tin oxide (ITO) under the same conditions. In addition, an ultralow sheet resistance of 0.36 Ω sq−1 at a transmittance, T, of 92% is achieved by combining mesoscale nanofibers with nanoscale metal wires.[17]
Moreover, transparent and conductive 1D nanomaterial networks could be stretchable without drastically altering electrical conductivity. These features are very difficult to achieve simultaneously in other types of nanomaterials because high optical transparency usually requires a very thin conductive film, which will inevitably cause cracking or breakage when a strain is applied.[18] This obstacle could be overcome by some specific 1D nanomaterials such as silver nanowires and ultrathin gold nanowires, due to their superior mechanical robustness and high aspect ratio. For example, a silver nanowire (Ag NW)/acrylate composite exhibited transmittances between 90.2% and 79.6% at 550 nm for sheet resistances between 50.8 and 7.5 Ω sq−1 with an increase in sheet resistance of 2.3× at 50% strain.[19] Furthermore, a high transparency of >90% at 550 nm and sheet resistance increase of

sections.heading: 3.1. Carbon Nanotubes
sections.text:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) offer several attributes for soft stretchable electronics, including high intrinsic carrier mobility[20] (10 000 cm2 V−1 s−1), high electrical conductivity (104 S cm−1),[21] superior mechanical performance (elastic modulus on the order of 1 TPa), and high chemical stability.[2]
Stretchable CNTs based electronics can be produced by either dispersing CNTs into a polymer matrix to form a CNT/ elastomer composite[22–27] (Figure 2a) or by directly depositing a CNT films onto stretchable substrates[28–33] (Figure 2b,c). The device performance could be further optimized by alignment of CNTs.[28,34–38] A number of techniques have been
developed to fabricate large-scale alignment of CNTs film with different morphologies, including vertically grown CNTs[34] (Figure 2d), buckled and aligned CNTs[35] (Figure 2e), and suspended CNTs[28] (Figure 2f).
In last decade, much effort has been made to fabricate intrinsically stretchable and conductive elastomers based on CNTs. Uniform dispersion of high quality CNTs is of utmost importance for producing large-area, highly conductive devices. It was reported that uniformly dispersed CNT pastes could be achieved by adding an ionic liquid to form chemically stable dopants into a fluorinated copolymer matrix.[22] Such CNTs paste was further modified to be compatible with direct printing techniques using a jet-milling process, due to the increased viscosity of the resulting single-walled nanotube (SWNT) rubber composite.[23]
Direct deposition of randomly distributed CNT film on soft substrates is another approach to realize stretchability, which can be achieved by either solution processing technique[29–32,39] or chemical vapor deposition.[33] The solution-processed CNTs film is usually deposited on top of elastomeric materials with

ie w or without encapsulation by another elastomeric layer. It is reported that a transparent CNT films could be spin-coated
on a poly(dimethyl siloxane) (PDMS) substrate.[39] The morphology and conductivity of such a film could be re-arranged upon stretching and releasing of the strain, which generated an isotropic spring-like structure of CNT bundles (Figure 2b). Moreover, a reticulated CNT network was demonstrated using floating catalyst chemical vapor deposition (FCCVD) and transferring to PDMS substrates (Figure 2c).[33] Benefiting from the hierarchical reticulate structure, the resultant SWCNT films own excellent electrical (2000 S cm−1) and mechanical (350 MPa) properties.
Horizontally aligned CNT ribbons could be directly drawn from vertically grown CNT forests (Figure 2d). CNT forests are typically grown using chemical vapor deposition (CVD). The unidirectional ribbons are ultrathin (tens of nanometers), extremely lightweight, transparent, and conductive, with the potential for large area fabrication using roll-to-roll techniques.[34] Stretchable conductors have been fabricated by a generating periodic wavy structure in the lateral direction,[27] as shown in Figure 2e. Such a buckled structure is produced using a pre-stretching strategy before CNT transferring. In addition
to this, aligned CNT films were also investigated for the application of crack-induced stretchable strain gauge sensors (Figure 2f).[28] When stretched, the nanotube films fracture into gaps and islands, with bundles bridging the gaps. This mechanism allows the films to measure strains up to 280% with high durability, fast response, and low creep. The optical transmittance of such a super-aligned CNT film can be improved by reducing the height of the CNT arrays through controlling the growth conditions[40] and laser/oxygen-plasma trimming of the CNT ribbons.[14] The conductivity can be enhanced by a crossstacked layout,[41] metal deposition,[34,35] or chemical doping.[42]

sections.heading: 3.2. Silver Nanowires
sections.text:
Silver nanowires (Ag NWs) are particularly attractive for stretchable and wearable electronics because Ag has the highest electrical conductivity among all the metal materials.[43] Several routes have been reported for the synthesis of Ag NWs including the polyol approach, the hydrothermal method, microwave-assisted process, electrochemical technique, UV irradiation technique, and template technique.[44] Among them,
Adv. Electron. Mater. 2017, 1600314
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (5 of 29) 1600314wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev iew the polyol approach[45–48] stands as the most commonly used procedure due to its ease of mass production, low cost, and simplicity. In addition, facile and large area deposition methods of Ag NWs have been developed to meet the requirement of large scale fabrication of soft electronics. For instance, a Meyer rod coating strategy was employed for scalable roll-to-roll deposition of Ag NWs networks (Figure 3a), which exhibited a sheet resistance of 8 Ω sq−1 and diffusive transmittance of 80%.[49] Other strategy including spray coating[50,51] and ultrafiltration[52–54] are also promising for large scale fabrication. The conductivity of Ag NWs could be improved by growing longer NWs, because of the longer percolation paths and reduced NW junctions.[52] In this case, a multistep growth method was developed for synthesis of very long Ag NWs, where AgNO3 was reduced repeatedly in ethylene glycol in the presence of PVP.[52,54] Figure 3b showed the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of very long Ag NWs after seven times of growth and the flexible LED arrays connected by patterned Ag NWs electrodes. The average length and aspect ratio of such Ag NWs were reported to be 96.1 µm and ≈600, respectively. Other strategies to further improve conductivity of Ag NWs film including reducing junction resistance by soldering with thermal annealing,[55–58] mechanical pressure,[59] laser or plasma treatment,[60,61] and introducing hybrid structure.[62,63] Stretchable conductors prepared using a Ag NW/polymer composite or mixture have been explored extensively with various layouts. For instance, a highly conductive and stretchable Ag NWs conductor was developed by embedding the Ag NWs network below the surface of PDMS (Figure 3c).[64] The Ag NW/PDMS wavy structure could maintain a very high conductivity of 5285 S cm−1 after a few stretching/releasing cycles at 50%. To reduce the hysteresis during stretching, a sandwiched PDMS/Ag NW/PDMS composite for the application of strain sensing was demonstrated. The composite showed excellent performance under both static and dynamic strain (ε > 40%) with a high linearity and negligible hysteresis, where large hysteresis was observed with simple Ag NW/PDMS composite.[65] Based on the sandwich design, a stretchable heater made of
Adv. Electron. Mater. 2017, 1600314
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1600314 (6 of 29) wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev
ie w a homogeneous nanocomposite of Ag NWs and styrene-buta-diene-styrene (SBS) elastomer (Figure 3d) was introduced.[66]
The mesh heater is light weight and thin, and is conformably integrated with the human joints and the skin for effective heat transfer and thermotherapy.
In addition to 2D film-based layout, hierarchical 3D assemblies and 1D-fiber-based structures were also reported. A hierarchical 3D structure was demonstrated using a binary network structure of polyurethane sponge (PUS)-Ag NWs-PDMS stretchable conductors.[67] The resulting PUS-Ag NW-PDMS stretchable conductors exhibit high electrical conductivity (>19.2 S cm−1) and excellent electromechanical stability under high tensile strain (50%) and a small bend radius (1 mm) because of the combined effects from the binary network. The same group then used oriented growth of ice to guide the assembly of Ag NWs for the fabrication of highly ordered hierarchical aerogel (Figure 3e).[68] The 3D monoliths can be embedded into elastomer (PDMS) as a stretchable and foldable conductor with high conductivity (12.5 S cm−1) and stable electromechanical performance. Moreover, fiber-based 1D Ag NWs architecture has been used as a low-cost stretchable and highly conductive core electrode (Figure 3f), which was coated with piezoresistive rubber to form a core-shell fiber.[69] Pressure sensors form at each cross contact between such fibers, and the sensitivity of the sensor unit can keep more than 50% of its original value even the tensile strain of sensor electrodes increases up to 100%.

sections.heading: 3.3. Copper Nanowires
sections.text:
CNTs and Ag NWs have been extensively explored as the main candidates for the application of soft electronics. However, the conductance of CNTs is still quite low, while Ag NWs unavoidably face cost or low-abundance issues when considered for real-world applications. Despite their outstanding performance, copper nanowires (Cu NWs) may offer cost benefits for commercial applications of soft conductors and sensors because of the high copper abundance on earth.[70,71] Typically, Cu NWs can be synthesized by solution-phase chemical reduction,[70–75] microwave-assisted process,[76] self-catalytic growth,[77] and electrospinning.[78,79] However, the properties of the films based on Cu NWs were not as good as those made with Ag NWs, due to their relatively lower aspect ratio, higher tendency for oxidation, and poorer solvent dispersion.[70–72] A number of methods have been developed to improve the performance of Cu NWs film in terms of large scale fabrication, conductivity, transparency, and stretchability. In 2005, a solution-phase chemical reduction of Cu(NO3)2 with hydrazine in an aqueous solution containing NaOH and ethylenediamine (EDA) was first introduced for the synthesis of Cu NWs.[74] This process could be scaled up by a factor or 200 (from 0.006 g to 1.2 g).[70,72] However, the performance of the as-synthesized Cu NW film (transmittance of 67% and a sheet resistance of 61Ω sq−1) is not comparable to that of Ag NWs or an ITO film (Figure 4a). In addition, a large scale and facile hydrothermal approach to synthesize a large amount of Cu NWs using a commercial electric pressure cooker was reported.[75] Oleylamine and oleic acid were used as dual surfactants of Cu NWs and glucose was used as
the reducing agent. Four liters of the reaction solution was prepared with an average diameter of 45 nm and lengths of 60–90 µm while obtaining a quantity of grams (over ≈2 g) in a batch. More recently, a transparent electrode based on Cu NWs with a sheet resistance of 51.5Ω sq−1 at 93.1% transmittance was demonstrated.[80] A nearly constant transmittance over the UV–vis–NIR range and a high ratio of electrical conductivity to optical conductivity were achieved.[77,80] Moreover, Cu NW-based conductors were achieved by a Cu NW–poly(vinylalcohol) (PVA) aerogel (Figure 4b).[71] The addition of PVA served as the stabilizer of the Cu NWs scaffolds, which largely enhanced the mechanical strength (Young’s modulus increased ≈30 times with 10% of PVA addition) of the Cu NWs monolith.[81] The highly porous structure was fabricated using a freeze drying process and could be embedded with PDMS to form an elastic amber. The as-prepared Cu NW-PVA-PDMS amber could bear both compressive and tensile strain of up to 60% with almost no resistance change. Other elastic polymers, such as poly(acrylate),[82] polyurethane,[83] and Eco-flex,[84] were also reported for the construction of wearable electronic devices with Cu NWs.
In addition, Cu NWs showed a high tendency for oxidation even in a short period, thus preventing their further application in real-world industries. To tackle this issue, a new Cu@ Cu4Ni NW conductive elastomer composite was developed with ultrahigh stability (Figure 4c).[85] Cu@Cu4Ni NWs have highly crystalline alloyed shells, which effectively prevent the Cu NWs from oxidizing. The fluctuation amplitude of resistance is in the range of 2 Ω sq−1 within 30 days, meaning that the actual lifetime at ΔR/R0 < 1 is estimated to be more than 1200 days. The environmental stability of Cu NWs could also be improved by plasmonic welding,[84] coating with grapheme oxide platelet,[86] and polymer stabilization.[87]
Furthermore, Cu NWs have a tendency for aggregation, which makes it hard to use them as a true ink for drawable electronics. As a result, we developed a method to fabricate homogeneous and well dispersed Cu NWs suspension by adding hydroxypropyl cellulose (HPC) (Figure 4d).[88] This versatile ink can be applied onto various substrates such as paper, PET, PDMS, and latex. By using the ink in a roller ball pen, devices like strain sensors, bending sensors, and conductive paint could be simply drawn on soft substrates, which showed high durability (>10 000 cycles) as well as excellent sensitivity (gauge factor = 54.38).

sections.heading: 3.4. Gold Nanowires
sections.text:
In recent years, gold nanowires (Au NWs) have attracted considerable interest as active components of electronic devices because of their chemical inertness, biocompatibility, and high electrical conductivity.[89] Various synthesis methods were developed to promote the utilization of Au NWs, including chemical reduction,[90,91] electrodeposition,[92] lithography/lift-off processes,[93] and slicing thin Au films.[94] However, most of the early reported techniques resulted in the production of polycrystalline or relatively large diameter (45 nm) nanowires with low aspect ratios and rough surfaces.[91] The thick and short nanowires are intrinsically rigid and show poor mechanical/electrical
Adv. Electron. Mater. 2017, 1600314
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (7 of 29) 1600314wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev iew
properties similar to traditional Ag NWs and Cu NWs, which is not favorable for their application in the field of soft electronics.
In 2008, the synthesis of ultrathin Au NWs (<5 nm) was developed[90,91,95] by using oleylamine (OA) or combined chemicals as both 1D growth templates and reducing agents (Figure 5a). Unlike other 1D nanomaterials, which are straight with high persistence length, ultrathin Au NWs are serpentine at the nanoscale behaving like “polymer chains” due to their ultrathin nature (2 nm in width, with an aspect ratio of >10 000),[96] as shown in Figure 5b. Hence, ultrathin Au NWs is intrinsically stretchable thus showing great promise to be used for stretchable electronic devices. For instance, a method to directly grow ultrathin Au NWs on a flexible substrate over a large area was reported by functionalization of the substrate.[97] Our group further developed a stretchable and transparent nanomembrane using ultrathin Au NWs.[98] The single-layer self-assembled thin film is mechanically flexible and electrically conductive, with an optical transmittance of 90–97% over a wide spectral window of 300–1100 nm. However, the resultant film exhibited a high electrical resistance of ≈1142 kΩ sq−1, due to the lack of junctions between nanowires after paralleled self-assembling. As a result, we designed a mesh-like Au NW
thin film exhibiting a figure of merit ≈25 times higher than single-layer self-assembled film,[99] which could be directly used for flexible touch screen (Figure 5c)[99] and transparent stretchable supercapacitors.[18]
Moreover, Au NW thin films also exhibited excellent sensitivity when serving as active materials in wearable sensors. For example, a flexible and highly sensitive pressure sensor could be fabricated by sandwiching ultrathin AuNW-impregnated tissue paper between two thin PDMS sheets (Figure 5d).[100] A wide range of pressure could be detected by the contact resistance changes between the AuNW/tissue composite and the underneath interdigitated electrodes. Another example used Au NW ink that could be directly written or screen printed on soft substrates for the fabrication of skin-attachable strain gauge sensors (Figure 5e).[96,101] The resultant Au NW thin film allowed stretchability of up to 350% with a high gauge factor of up to 60.[96]

sections.text:
One-dimensional zinc oxide (ZnO) nanowires have received extensive attention for strain sensors and wearable energy devices because of their novel hierarchical structure, high

electron mobility, and unique piezoelectric properties.[102] Many approaches are available to fabricate ZnO nanowires, while the hydrothermal method is the most frequently used.[103] In 2008, strain sensors based on hierarchical ZnO nanowires were first fabricated by bonding a ZnO PFW laterally on a polystyrene (PS) substrate.[102] The combined effects from strain induced band structure change and piezoelectricity result in the change of Schottky barrier height (SBH). High sensitivity with a gauge factor of 1250 was demonstrated, however, with very limited stretchability (<1.5%). A similar design was also used for the construction of flexible self-power devices[103] and flexible energy devices.[104] To fabricate highly stretchable electronics, ZnO nanowires were grown on elastic fibers such as polystyrene[105] and polyurethane[106] to form a hybrid structure. Stretchability of 150% could be achieved using this strategy. The sensor offered additional features including temperature and UV monitoring.[106]

sections.heading: 3.6. 1D Polymeric Nanomaterials
sections.text:
1D polymer nanomaterials offer a variety of benefits, including large surface area, high aspect ratio and excellent softness when compared to inorganic nanomaterials. The 1D polymer nanomaterials could be fabricated either using a templated-based method or a template-free method. The template method has been widely explored for conductive polymers, where both hard templates (anodic aluminum oxide, particle track etched membranes, titanium dioxide nanotube arrays,etc.)[107–109] and soft templates (such as cylindrical micelles)[110] were applied for the construction of 1D configurations based on chemical/electrochemical polymerization. However, the template methods suffer from complicated processes, limited scalability, and high cost, and are therefore not favorable for application in wearable and soft electronics.[8,110]
Alternately, template-free methods based on electrospinning have been extensively developed to overcome the above
limitations. Electrospinning is regarded as a simple and versatile approach for fabricating uniform ultrafine fibers in a continuous process.[111] The electrospun polymer fibers exhibited a variety of outstanding properties, such as high aspect ratio, tunable surface morphologies, and superior mechanical performance. There are mainly two strategies to fabricate electrospun fibers for the construction of flexible/stretchable electronics: direct electrospinning of conductive polymers[112–119] or electrospinning non-conductive polymers with conductive depositing.[17,120–122]
Conductive polymers such as poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythi ophene):poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS), poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT), and piezoelectric polymers such as poly(vinylidenefluoride-co-trifluoroethylene) (P(VDF-TrFe)) have been successfully electrospun into 1D nanofibers for flexible/stretchable electronic devices (Figure 6a,b).[112–119] Such devices offer exceptional sensitivity for measuring pressure, bending, and strain with advanced features including selfpower and lightweight. However, it should be noted that the conductivity of the as-spun fibers decreases remarkably,[123] which hinders their applications for flexible/stretchable transparent conductors. To further improve the conductivity, non-conductive polymers are electrospun into nanofibers, which are used as a template for conductive deposition by sputtering, evaporation, in situ polymerization, electroless deposition, and so on.[17,120–122] Flexible/stretchable electrodes could be realized with superior transparency, flexibility, and conductivity. For instance, a transparent conducting electrode based on a metal/PVA nanotrough network was developed with both superior optoelectronic performances (sheet resistance of ≈2 Ω−1 at 90% transmission) and remarkable mechanical flexibility under stretching and bending stresses (Figure 6c,d).[120] The optoelectrical performance could be further enhanced to a sheet resistance of ≈0.36 Ω−1 at 92% transmission by a combination of mesoscale microfibers and nanoscale nanofibers.[17]

sections.heading: 3.7. Hybrid Structures
sections.text:
Each material has its own strength and weakness, and the resulting wearable electronics based on a single material type inevitably suffer from various limitations.[124] The combination of two or more materials into hybrid nanocomposites showed great promise to compensate the disadvantage of single materials while keeping the advantages of each material. A binary composite of 0D/1D systems, 1D/1D systems, and 1D/2D systems have been extensively explored for the use of stretchable electronics, including a CNT/Ag composite,[124–129] CNT/graphene composite,[130–132] Ag/graphene composite,[133] Au NWs/ polyaniline composite,[96] etc. In 2014, a Ag NW/CNT hybrid nanocomposite was designed for highly stretchable and highly transparent and flexible conductors.[124] In this binary system, highly conductive Ag NW percolation networks provide backbone current collector electrodes for fast electron transport, while an elastic SWCNT percolation network endows high stretchability and flexibility and further enhances the conductivity throughproviding local electron transport paths by filling the inter-nanowire space of the backbone electrode of Ag NW mesh (Figure 7a). The Ag NW/CNT hybrid nanocomposite demonstrated highly stretchable (>460%) conductors with remarkable mechanical reliability over long repeated bending (>10 000 times), large twisting (>540°), and folding (≈0°, complete folding), and high transparency (80–93%); they showed superior mechanical compliance and electrical conductivity compared to single component materials such as CNT only or Ag NW only.[125]
In addition to the 1D/1D system, 0D structures also serve as a premium additive to substantially improve the conductivity
of 1D nanomaterials. For instance, micrometer-sized silver flakes (n-Ag) were used in combination with multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) for the construction of highly conductive, printable, and stretchable hybrid composites (Figure 7b).[128] The nanotubes were used as 1D flexible and conductive scaffolds to construct effective electrical networks among the silver flakes. The hybrid composite exhibited a high conductivity of 5710 S cm−1 at 0% strain. However, the conductivity decreased dramatically to 20 S cm−1 at 140% strain because of the disconnection of the low-aspect-ratio Ag flask at high strains. In addition, we demonstrated a simple yet efficient approach to dope polyaniline (PANI) microparticles into Au NWs films, leading to 10 times enhancement in conductivity and simultaneously ≈8 times improvement in sensitivity.[96] The hybrid film also showed reversible and repeatable response of as much as 150% upon strain due to the relatively low concentration of 0D PANI microparticles in the composite. Flexible electronics made of ordered Au-Te hetero-nanowire films were reported with a
tric resistance of the ultrathin flexible film can be easily tuned from MΩ to Ω by tuning the concentration of Au nanoparticles, generating reliable inter-connections for LED arrays (Figure 7c).
Graphene typically shows poor electrical and mechanical stretchability because of structural defects or large interlayer resistance,[136] which restricts its application in soft electronics. To enhance the conductivity and stretchability, introducing CNTs[137] and metal nanowires[138] have been developed. Lee et al. coated a thin layer of a Ag NW network on top of graphene films to effectively improve the conductivity, where Ag NWs act as connecting bridge between graphene sheets.[133] Consequently, a low resistance of 33 Ω sq−1 at a high transmittance of 94% was achieved. Graphene/Ag NW on PDMS exhibited a large strain tolerance of 100% with negligible resistance degradation. The thermal stability of the hybrid film is much better than that of pure Ag NWs. In addition, a hierarchically structured carbon microfiber made of an interconnected network of aligned SWCNTs with interposed nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide sheets was demonstrated (Figure 7d).[132] The nanocomposite formed mesoporous structures of large specific surface area (396 m2 g−1) with high electrical conductivity (102 S cm−1). A wearable supercapacitor based on the resulting microfiber had a volumetric energy density of ≈6.3 mWh cm−3 with a long cycle life.
The key parameters of soft devices based on several 1D nanomaterials, including the stretchability, conductivity, sensitivity, transparency, cost, and stability, are shown in Table 1. CNTs and ultrathin gold nanowires could significantly enhance the stretchability of conductive thin films, with minute reduction of conductivity upon stretching, benefiting from their serpentine and high-aspect-ratio morphology. However, the conductivity of
Adv. Electron. Mater. 2017, 1600314
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1600314 (10 of 29) wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev
ie w
these materials is usually low (Table 1). Consequently, CNTs and ultrathin Au NWs are widely used for voltage driven devices, such as stretchable electrodes for strain and pressure sensors and capacitive touch screens, where high conductivity is not required. In comparison, Ag NW- and Cu NW-based electronics exhibited great potential as transparent and flexible electrodes because of their high conductivity. However, the resulting devices are usually more rigid than those from CNTs and AuNWs. As a result, Ag NWs and Cu NWs are more suitable for current driven devices such as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) and solar cells in which high conductivity is essential. Zinc oxide nanowires showed ultrahigh pizoresistivity because of their chirality and change in barrier height.[102–105] Therefore, highly sensitive strain gauge could be achieved with ZnO nanowires, but with limited stretchability (ε < 5%) that is far lower than the requirement for skin-mountable strain sensors (ε > 50%). Although new approaches such as forming a composite with stretchable polymers could be used to achieve high stretchability, the sensitivity of such ZnO nanowire based strain sensors was largely decreased due to the fact that piezoresistive effect was no longer the dominate contribution to the total resistance–strain performance. Nanowires electrospun by conductive polymers exhibited high sensitivity for the application of flexible strain sensors, but their conductivity is limited due to the addition of non-conducting polymers or chemicals.[123] On the other hand, polymer fibers with metal deposition exhibited both high transparency and conductivity, which are attractive for the fabrication of flexible/stretchable transparent conductors.[17,120–122] Hybrid composites could effectively compensate the disadvantages of single materials with both enhanced conductivity and stretchability and have been widely applied for stretchable conductors and sensing devices.

sections.heading: 4. Fabrication Methods
sections.text:
As-synthesized 1D nanomaterials may be in dry or wet forms. An appropriate processing method is critical for optimizing device performance to be suitable for particular applications. Typically, we can classify the fabrication methods into three categories: direct coating methods,[39,49,50,55,67,101] transferring methods,[18,54,85,98,139] and printing/drawing methods.[88,96,140,141] Direct coating methods allowed solution-based nanomaterial deposited on soft substrates through techniques, such as drop-casting,[101] dip-coating,[67] Meyer rod coating,[49] spray coating,[50,142–144] and spin coating[39] (Figure 8a–d). We have recently reported highly stretchable and sensitive strain sensors based on the ultrathin AuNWs/latex nanocomposite.[101] The Au NW network thin films were deposited onto a maskdefined latex matrix using a pipette. A stretchable conductor was also demonstrated by dip-coating Ag NWs on a polyurethane sponge.[67] The Ag NWs density on the sponge fiber was

Right: photograph of a twisted stretchable conductor completing an electrical circuit with a battery pack and a LED. Reproduced with permission.[124] b) SEM image and photograph of hybrid nAg+CNTs. Reproduced with permission.[128] Copyright 2010, Nature Publishing Group. c) SEM image and photograph of hybrid Te nanowire+Au nanoparticle. Reproduced with permission.[134] d) SEM image and photograph of hybrid CNT+graphene. Reproduced with permission.[132] Copyright 2014, Nature Publishing Group.

well-controlled by dip-coating cycles. Meyer rod coating was developed using Ag NWs ink, which is a promising, scalable method for the fabrication of transparent electrodes.[49] In this work, Ag NWs were coated directly from methanol without the need for an additional film-forming polymer. Other approaches, such as spray coating and spin coating, were mainly used to produce large-scale, smooth and flexible soft electronics. Although direct coating techniques showed great promise for large-scale and low-cost fabrication of wearable electronics, there were still some limitations including 1) the uniformity of the nanomaterials film is hard to control; and 2) the bonding interaction between nanomaterials and elastomeric substrates is weak.
Transferring nanomaterial membranes from the forming substrate to the elastomeric receiving substrate represents another viable strategy to fabricate soft electronic devices. The Ag NWs percolation network can be formed by vacuum filtration followed by transferring to the elastomeric substrate (Figure 8e).[54] The
film showed high uniformity in terms of thickness as the suction force is uniformly distributed on the filter paper. In addition, CVD was used for direct growth of a vertically aligned CNT thin film on silicon substrates.[34–37] In this method, carbon feedstock gases were supplied on a substrate decorated with catalyst particles under high temperature conditions (>800 °C). The as-grown thin films were then transferred to flexible substrates by direct drawing (Figure 8f).[34] Such a technique also showed potential for large-scale fabrication through a roll-to-roll process.[36] Well-aligned nanostructures could also be realized by self-assembly. We reported the fabrication of giant superlattice nanomembranes from ultrathin Au NWs via Langmuir–Blodgett (LB) techniques.[98] The free-standing nanomembranes could be transferred to both hydrophilic and hydrophobic substrates from the air–water interface (Figure 8g).
In addition, soft electronic devices can be printed or drawn directly on the target substrate, which can lead to miniaturized

sensors and devices with versatile patterns. For instance, a tattoo-like wearable sensor was fabricated simply by a direct “draw-on” strategy using a Chinese penbrush with Au NW solution as the ink (Figure 8h).[96] The stretchability of the sensors could be enhanced from 99.7% to 149.6% by designing curved tattoos with different radii of curvatures. In order to fabricate high precision patterns, we used a ball-point-pen instead of a brush for printing wearable electronics based on Cu NW ink (Figure 8i).[88] Trace line of <1 mm was drawn on a variety of substrates. Consequently, a complex conductive pattern depicting the Sydney Opera House was painted on paper, thus demonstrating the versatility and robustness of the technique. In addition, the inject printing technique was also used to fabricate soft electronics; the controlled printing of silver nanowires network allowed well-defined patterns from an optimized isopropyl alcohol−diethylene glycol dispersion (Figure 8j).[141] High resolution was achieved for line widths of 1−10 mm and network thicknesses of 0.5−2 µm, which could realize complex patterns such as the Trinity College Dublin crest as shown in Figure 8j (right). Another method was reported using an embedded 3D printing technique where the viscous nanomaterial ink was directly embedded in elastomer films through a deposition nozzle.[145] It is even possible to align 1D nanomaterials into highly ordered arrays.[4] Oriented 1D nanostructures have the potential to lead to novel soft electronic devices in which spatial optoelectronic properties may be controlled directionally.[34] The approaches, including flow-assisted alignment,[146] LB,[98] contact printing,[4] and CVD,[34] have been adopted to fabricate highly oriented structures. Some applications of the aligned nanomaterial-based stretchable conductors,[35] wearable sensors,[28] and wearable energy harvesting,[147] have also been recently reported.

sections.text:
Wearable and stretchable electronic devices require simultaneous achievement of outstanding optoelectronic functions and high mechanical compliance/robustness; these requirements have been fulfilled to some degree by the use of 1D nanomaterials. This

sections.heading: 5.1. Stretchable Conductors
sections.text:
A stretchable conductor is a critical component in nearly all soft electronic devices, as it works as the interconnect for each active component in an integrated multifunctional device. Current achievements in stretchable electronics have largely been attributed to advances in stretchable, compliant conductors.[149] Stretchability and conductivity remain two crucial parameters to evaluate the performance of a stretchable conductor. To achieve both high stretchability and conductivity, several methods have been explored, mainly based on materials design,structure design, or the combination of both.[1] Due to their large aspect ratio, 1D nanomaterials are excellent candidates as the conductive materials for stretchable conductors[9] The common strategy is to disperse a conductive thin film onto elastomeric materials. The resistance of the resulting composite is generally sensitive to the strain, due to the materials mismatch between conductive thin film and elastic substrate. Another method to enhance the stretchability is to disperse conductive filler into
an elastic matrix to form a conductive composite. Parameters such as the weight ratio between conductive fillers and elastic polymers, filler distribution, homogeneity, and orientation play a vital role in the mechanical and electrical performance of the composites.[150] High loading of conductive materials results in high conductivity but reduces the stretchability of the composite.[151,152] Techniques like addition of surfactants,[150] ultrasonication,[152] jet-milling,[26] hot pressing,[129] shear mixing,[153] and exfoliation agents mixing[22,23,111] have been adopted to improve the homogeneity of the composite.The conductive filler/stretchable polymer matrix is stretchable with reasonable conductivity, but the conductivity still decreases with the applied strain due to the decreased contact points between the nanomaterials as a result of sliding. In this case, structural design is combined with 1D nanomaterial composites to realize stable conductance with minor influence by strain.
Both the microstructure and the geometrical shape of 1D nanomaterial thin films could be designed to improve their electrical stability upon stretching. Mechanical buckling has been demonstrated to be a promising approach to achieve micro “wavy” structures on elastomeric substrates. The buckling structure could be introduced either by prestrain-transfer-release process[9] or multiple strain-release process.[18,39] The process of prestrain–transfer-release is illustrated in Figure 9a, where additional deformation of substrates will result in spontaneous
Adv. Electron. Mater. 2017, 1600314
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1600314 (14 of 29) wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev
ie w formation of periodic, wavy structures of 1D nanomaterials thin film after releasing. Upon stretching, the wavy structure
accommodates the strain by the increased buckling wavelength and decreased buckling amplitude, rendering much less strain inside the materials themselves.[9] As a result, the electric resistance remains nearly constant during the stretching. Such a “wavy” structure could also be realized by multiple strain-release strategy. Figure 9b showed a wavy Au NWs thin film after multiple strain-release processes.[18] Upon repeated stretching– releasing process, Au NW thin films slide on the substrate to accommodate deformation and finally form a buckle structure. The resistance typically exhibits a dependence on strain history, at first several stretching–releasing cycles, and achieves a stable value when the buckled structure is formed.[18,39]
Geometrical shape design for 1D nanomaterials has been widely used for the fabrication of stretchable conductors by techniques such as writing,[88,96] twisting,[154] molding,[155] and printing.[141,156] Patterns including serpentine structure,[88,96,156] spring-like structure,[154] helical structure,[155] and net-shaped structure[157] can accommodate most of the strain by the shape change, thus maintain the conductive pathways during strain. For instance, an all-printed stretchable electrode was demonstrated based on a serpentine line of CNTs (Figure 9c).[156] Because of the combination of structural design and 1D structure of CNTs, the electrode withstands extremely large levels of strain (up to 500%) with negligible effect on its structural integrity and performance. As another stretchable design, a 3D helical structure can be formed by PDMS patterning using straw as the helical mold.[155] The PDMS helical wire was then covered with a Cu NW thin film as a highly stretchable electrode. The resulting electrode exhibited a large strain of 700% without obvious changes in resistance.

sections.heading: 5.2. Wearable Pressure Sensors
sections.text:
A pressure sensor usually acts as a transducer that transforms an imposed force into an electrical signal or other recognized signal output.[158] There are mainly three transduction
mechanisms for pressure sensors, namely capacitance, piezoresistivity, and piezoelectricity. Each transduction method has its own characteristics.
Capacitance pressure sensors transduce the capacitance change of a device into an electrical signal (Figure 10a). In a traditional parallel plate capacitor, capacitance is given by the equation:
/r 0C A dε ε= (3)
where C is the capacitance, εr is the relative static permittivity of the material between the plates, ε0 is the dielectric constant, A is the area of overlap of the two plates in square meters, and d is the separation between the plates in meters. In a capacitance pressure sensor set-up, an applied pressure causes d and A changes. This change may or may not be linear and is usually on the order of several picofarads (pF). For the purpose of skinattachable, capacitance-based wearable pressure sensor required both electrodes to be stretchable. In this case 1D nanomaterials are frequently used as electrode materials. For example, a transparent pressure and strain sensor was demonstrated based on a spray-deposited CNT film.[39] The spring-like structure of CNTs accommodated strains of up to 150% and conductivities as high as 2200 S cm−1 in the stretched state. The capacitance sensor was composed of two strips of PDMS bearing stretchable CNTs films, which were laminated face-to-face, with Eco-flex silicone elastomer as a spacer. Both applied pressure and tensile strain (Figure 11a) resulted in a shortened distance between the electrodes, which caused capacitance changes (Figure 11b). However, the relatively small change in the capacitance hampered their application for the detection of tiny pressures. To achieve higher sensitivity, the same group designed a microstructured film as the dielectric layer of capacitance sensors.[159] The micropyramid patterns could effectively reduce the contact area between the electrode and the dielectric layer, leading to quick responses and enhanced sensitivity upon applied pressure.
The principle of piezoresistive sensors is based on transducing the resistance change of a device into an electrical signal (Figure 10b). These sensors have been investigated extensively
Adv. Electron. Mater. 2017, 1600314
© 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim (15 of 29) 1600314wileyonlinelibrary.com
R ev iew
because of their simple device structures, easy read-out mechanism, low power consumption, and potentially high pixel density.[160] The electrical signal change is mainly caused by contact resistance between two conductive materials when a pressure is applied.[161] Our group developed wearable pressure sensors using ultrathin gold nanowires (Figure 11c) by sandwiching tissue paper impregnated ultrathin AuNWsbetween two PDMS films.[100] The pressure sensor exhibited high sensitivity (>1.14 kPa−1), fast response time (<17 ms), and good wearability due to the soft nature of the ultrathin Au NWs. In addition, the device could effectively differentiate between pressing, bending, and torsional forces (Figure 11d), which allowed real-time monitoring of human wrist pulse and acoustic vibration. The sensitivity of the wearable pressure sensor could be further improved by micropatterns such as micro-domes[25] and micro-pyramids.[161] A piezoresistive pressure sensor based on CNTs/PDMS conductive composite was reported.[25,26] The elastic composite could be shaped into interlocked micro-dome arrays templated by a silicone mold. Two interlocked film were then assembled faceto-face. The contact area of conductive patterns changed when a pressure was applied, thus leading to resistance changes of the device. This design allowed detection of a large pressure range from 0.2 Pa to 59 kPa. As a result, multiple applications were realized, including breath detection and gas flow detection.
Piezoelectricity is another commonly used transduction method for pressure sensors. Piezoelectricity refers to electrical charges generated in certain types of solid materials (such as crystals and certain ceramics) in response to applied mechanical stress.[162] The occurrence of electric dipole moments in solids contributes to the piezoelectric effect (Figure 10c).[150] There are several advantages of piezoelectric sensors including wide frequency response range, high sensitivity to dynamic pressures, and low power consumption (or even no need for power).[163,164] Benefitting from these merits, piezoelectric sensors are widely used in the detection of dynamic pressures such as vibrations of sound and slip.[2] However, compared with the resistive and capacitive method of pressure/strain sensing, the piezoelectric
films are not well-suited to sense static pressures or loads because the piezoelectric effect is transient in nature. Thus, a voltage is generated only when the load is applied, which subsequently decays quickly via dissipative resistive pathways. Additionally, piezoelectric films such as PVDF exhibit significant temperature sensitivity, known as the pyroelectric effect, which may affect the ability to reliably detect absolute pressure values without the use of temperature sensors for compensation.[165]
Pressure sensors based on other transduction methods, such as optical pressure sensors and resonant pressure sensors, are envisioned to be applicable for touch screens or force collectors.[158] However, the wearability of the above-mentioned sensors needs to be improved due to the rigid active material and design. Furthermore, triboelectric sensors that utilize contact electrification to generate a voltage signal in response to physical contact are frequently used in flexible pressure sensors.[166–172] Such devices could function without reliance on an external power supply and showed great promise for the application of pressure mapping,[167–169] security surveillance,[170] health monitoring,[170] and motion detection.[171] However, the required gap and the air exchange during mechanical deformation make the package of such a sensor rather challenging, particularly for applications in severe environments such as in dusty or moisture atmosphere, which are known to largely eliminate surface triboelectric charges and reduce the output. A strategy based on a hemisphere-array-structure has been developed for fully packaging triboelectric sensors; this uses a structure firmly built in an enclosed and packaged system without any spacer.[172]

sections.heading: 5.3. Stretchable Strain Gauge Sensors
sections.text:
Strain sensors respond to the applied strain with different mechanisms. the strain–capacitance response of traditional strain gauges relies on geometrical effects, which is similar to the capacitance pressure sensors discussed above. The strain–resistance response sensors mainly originate from

piezoresistivity of materials themselves, disconnection between sensing elements, and crack propagation.[173]
1D nanomaterials such as individual CNT and zinc oxide (ZnO) nanowires showed ultrahigh piezoresistivity upon structural deformation due to their chirality and change in barrier height.[173] Strain sensors based on single CNTs[174] or zinc oxide nanowires[102] usually exhibited ultrahigh gauge factors of >800 with limited stretchability (<5%) that is far lower than the requirement of skin-attachable and wearable strain sensors (ε > 50%). New approaches have been proposed for achieving high stretchability by forming composites of 1D nanomaterials with stretchable polymers.[105,106,175] However, the strain sensitivity of the resultant sensors decreased dramatically due to the large elastic mismatch between 1D nanomaterials and matrix polymers, yielding negligible deformations of conductive materials upon stretching.[24]
In the disconnection mechanism, electrons could pass through overlapped 1D nanomaterial thin film within the percolation network. When strain is applied to the thin film, the connection points of overlapped nanomaterials will decrease, consequently increasing the electrical resistance. From a microstructural point of view, disconnection of overlapped nanomaterials under stretching is caused by the slippage of nanomaterials due to the weak interfacial binding and large stiffness mismatch between nanomaterials and stretchable polymers.[24,65,173] The density of 1D nanomaterials is a key parameter for the disconnection mechanism. Figure 12a illustrates numerical analysis of the low and high density Ag NW networks[65] when a strain is applied. Bottlenecks emerged in the low-density AgNWs network, where the electrical conductivity is limited upon stretching, resulting in a sharp nonlinear increase in the resistance. On the other hand, emergence of the bottlenecks was less probable in the case of the high-density network because of large number of connected NWs within the
percolation network.[65] The corresponding numerical simulation of total resistance changes versus applied strain agreed well with the experimental results (Figure 12b). Figure 12c illustrates the number of disconnected NWs and tunneling junctions upon stretching. The number of disconnected NWs linearly increased with the applied strain whereas tunneling junctions were very small and their piezoresistive effect was negligible. This indicates the thin film Ag NWs strain sensor is mainly based on disconnection between wires upon stretching.
Crack propagation in 1D nanomaterial thin films contributes to another sensing mechanism for wearable strain gauge sensors. Cracks tend to initiate in the stress concentrated areas to release the accommodated stress. Microcracks were generated in CNT,[28] Ag NW,[156] Cu NW,[88] and Au NW[96,101] thin films coated on elastomeric substrates under stretching. Stretching led to opening and enlargement of microcracks in thin films, critically limiting the electrical conduction through thin films due to the separation of several microcrack edges.[28] Moreover, the electrical resistance of thin films drastically increased with the applied strain. This mechanism was used to develop highly sensitive and stretchable strain sensors. Figure 12d illustrated the surface morphology changes of a CNT/PDMS strain sensor during the stretching process from 0% to 100%. Upon initial stretching, irreversible cracks throughout the film created gaps and islands; with further strain, their numbers and the gap sizes increased.[28] A simple model to describe the resistance of the cracked film was demonstrated in Figure 12e. The resistance of the film after forming cracks could be calculated using Equation (4):

sections.heading: 5.4. Stretchable Power Supply Devices
sections.text: Stretchable energy harvesting and energy storage devices that can be intimately integrated with soft functional electronic devices are required to be used as continuous power supply for skin or cloth mounted portable and mobile systems.[176] Conventional active materials, such as inorganic materials (e.g., carbon black, active carbon) can only allow narrow range of strain (<5%) before fracture or failure.[177] In addition, stretchable supercapacitors based on graphene or conductive polymers (e.g., PEDOT:PSS, PANI, Ppy) usually exhibited poor cycling stretchability, which may be attributed to the intrinsic defects of the sheet or polymer based electrode materials.[178] In this case, 1D nanomaterials (e.g., CNTs, Ag NWs) have been widely used as electrode materials for stretchable supercapacitors because of their ideal nanoscale wire-based structures.

sections.heading: 5.4.1. Stretchable Supercapacitors
sections.text:
As a vital component of energy devices, 1D nanomaterialbased supercapacitors showed great potential to power portable electronic devices due to their exceptional conductivity and excellent cycling stretchability. The electrical switchability of such supercapacitors
could be achieved either by pre-stretching of elastic substrates before nanomaterials coating[42,179–184] or by using textile configurations.[185,186] Based on their geometries, we could divide the supercapacitors into three subgroups: 1) 1D wire based stretchable supercapacitors, 2) 2D film based stretchable supercapacitors, and 3) 3D textile based stretchable supercapacitors.
1D wire- or fiber-based stretchable supercapacitors have several advantages when compared with their planar counterparts, such as being lightweight and easily integrated.[179,180] In 2013, a stretchable wire-shaped stretchable supercapacitor was reported for the first time.[179] The excellent stretchability of the supercapacitor was achieved by wrapping aligned CNT sheets on elastic fibers. The specific capacitance of the supercapacitor was maintained by >95% after stretching 100 cycles at 75% strain. High contact areas between the electrode and electrolyte are well maintained, benefitting from the coaxial structure of wires. Following this work, a twisted wire-shape design was introduced to further optimize the stretchability of the wire-based supercapacitor.[180] By wrapping a continuous CNT thin film around pre-stretched elastic wires, a conductive electrode with an extremely high elasticity up to 300% strain
was achieved (Figure 13a). The stretchable supercapacitors were fabricated by twisting two wires pre-coated with PVA/H3PO4 electrolyte. The resultant supercapacitor could be stretched with almost no change in performance, indicating good stretching stability of this design (Figure 13b). Furthermore, a superelastic supercapacitor was demonstrated using aligned CNT/PANI electrodes wrapped around an eco-flex fiber.[181] The specific capacitance of the supercapacitor was well maintained at a high stretching speed (30 mm s−1) and multiple cyclic stretching at a high strain of 300%.
The 2D film shape is the most commonly used design for supercapacitors due to controllable fabrication process and relatively high specific area. In 2009, a 2D stretchable supercapacitor was reported based on buckled SWCNT films.[182] The reversible stretchability was achieved by bonding thin active layer of SWCNT on pre-strained elastomeric substrate. A wavy-like structure was yielded on the substrate after releasing (Figure 13c). After assembling two sinusoidal SWCNT film electrodes with electrolyte sandwiched in between, the device could withstand stretchability of 30% while retaining functionality up to 1000 charge–discharge cycles (Figure 13d).[183]

The stretchability of the buckling electrodes could be further improved up to 140% by combining reticulate architecture SWCNT films with pre-strained PDMS.[184] Recently, stretchable supercapacitors equipped with advanced features such as transparency[185] and chromatic transition[42] were achieved based on CNT sheets. However, the electrical performance of transparent stretchable supercapacitors is still poor compared to opaque ones, due to the decreased conductivity and stretchability with a much thinner conductive film.
A 3D textile-based stretchable supercapacitor was first reported by using SWNTs.[186] The stretchable electrodes were achieved using an extremely simple “dipping and drying” process with porous textile and high conductive CNT ink (Figure 13e); they showed a high conductivity of 125 S cm−1 and a low sheet resistance of < 1 Ω sq−1. Supercapacitors made from these conductive textiles (Figure 13f) showed no obvious change in specific capacitance before and after stretching of 120% for more than 2000 cycles. In addition, the 3D structure of the electrode can effectively increase the mass loading of active materials, benefiting from much higher specific area compared with 2D film-based electrodes. Furthermore, the strategy of pre-straining a textile before active materials depositing is proposed.[187] Interestingly, the textile electrodes showed a decrease in resistance with tensile strain due to the alignment of the CNTs. As a result, both specific capacitance and the power/energy densities of the supercapacitor were enhanced.

sections.heading: 5.4.2. Stretchable Batteries
sections.text:
A primary battery represents the most widely used energy storage devices since its first working independently by Thomas Edison in 1901. Nowadays primary alkali manganese cells occupy a dominant position in the portable battery market due
to their extremely low cost and easy disposal.[188,189] 1D nanomaterials mainly served as stretchable electroactive materials and current collectors for the design and fabrication of the primary battery. In 2014, a silver-zinc battery based on stretchable Ag NW and electroplated Zn electrodes was presented (Figure 14a).[190] The fully stretchable batteries maintained their functions even when stretched up to 80% (Figure 14b,c) and were stable over 1000 cycles. However, the energy density of this AgNW-Zn based battery (0.44 mWh cm−2) is lower than conventional printed silver-zinc batteries[191] (4 mWh cm−2) due to the much smaller active layer thickness. The capacity of stretchable electrodes can be further improved by methods such as designing porous structures[192] to increase the contact area of 1D nanomaterials with electrolytes.
Compared with primary battery, 1D nanomaterials based lithium-ion battery represents the future development direction of the industry for energy storage devices, due to its high energy density, long working life, and light weight.[192–195] A stretchable lithium-ion battery based on 1D nanomaterials was first obtained by introducing a porous CNT/PDMS/PMMA structure as the current collector for lithium ions.[192] The porous morphology can be well-controlled by verifying the weight ratio of PDMS/PMMA. However, this design can only achieve a low specific capacity (≈7 mAh g−1) because of the insufficient content of active material (PDMS/CNT = 20:1). The electrical performance of the battery was also not assessed under stretching. 1D wire-based stretchable lithium-ion batteries represent another direction for wearable energy storage and conversion devices. A novel stretchable lithium-ion battery was designed using aligned MWCNT/lithium oxide composite yarns (Figure 14d).[193] Such devices can be bent for >1000 cycles and stretched (100%) for >200 cycles with little decrease in capacity (Figure 14e,f). As an additional attribute, the wire-shaped batteries could be woven into lightweight battery textiles, which

Moreover, metal–air batteries have been widely studied as next-generation power systems because of their environmental friendliness, low cost, and potential high energy-storage capability.[196,197] In particular, flexible or stretchable metal–air batteries could be achieved in a fiber-shaped configuration. Such devices were made by sequentially coating a gel electrolyte and wrapping cross-stacked CNT sheets as the air cathode onto a spring-like Al or Zn substrate.[196,197] The cross-stacked CNT sheets produce a porous framework to effectively adsorb oxygen, which significantly enhance the energy-storage capability. More importantly, the CNT sheet, hydrogel electrolyte, and Al or Zn spring are flexible and stretchable.

sections.heading: 5.4.3. Wearable Solar Cells
sections.text:
Solar energy is a renewable and environmentally friendly energy source that has been recognized as one of the most promising choices to meet the enormous energy demand in the future.[8] Conventional planar solar cells have been developed with high power conversion efficiency (PCE). However, the flexibility and wearability of the planar configuration are limited due to the rigid nature of both the substrate and the active component. The earlier stretchable photovoltaic devices had rigid semiconductor elements connected using buckled interconnects onto elastomeric substrates. This geometry was designed to localize most of strain at the interconnects[198] to avoid rigid semiconductors being damaged upon stretching. In addition, attention has been focused on novel 1D nanomaterials due to the cracking-resistant nanowire morphology. For instance, a highly bendable ZnO nanowire film on a PET/ITO substrate was fabricated using low-temperature hydrothermal growth.[199] The film showed good mechanical properties with an extremely small bending radius of 2 mm because ZnO nanowires are vertically grown on substrates, which can thus efficiently avoid deformation in parallel direction upon bending.
Recently, 1D solar cells have attracted attention because of their unique advantages of flexibility, light weight, and weavability.[200] To further enhance the wearability of 1D solar cells, aligned CNT materials, mainly CNT fibers have been used as the electrode materials of solar cells. For example, an aligned CNT fiber and aligned TiO2 nanotube-modified Ti wire as two electrodes were twisted into a fiber-shaped polymer solar cell.[201] Such a design was further extended to stacking textile electrodes of CNT fibers and Ti wire textiles for more integrated wearable solar cells with high energy conversion efficiencies of up to 3.67%, which were well-maintained during bending[202] or stretching.[203] However, the metal wire electrode often has drawbacks including insufficient flexibility, poor corrosion resistance, and low surface area for integrating wire shaped solar cells. As a result, a wearable double-twisted perovskite solar cell with both CNT fibers as electrodes was developed. The anode CNT fiber was coated by a thin layer of compact n-TiO2, meso-TiO2, CH3NH3PbI3-xClx, poly(3-hexylthiophene)/singlewalled carbon nanotube (P3HT/SWNT), and Ag NW network
from the inside out, and finally twisted with another CNT fiber electrode. The Ag NW network was used to increase the effective contact area between two CNT fiber electrodes. The perovskite solar cell showed flexible reliability maintained for larger than 1000 bending cycles with a maximum PCE of 3.03%.[204]

sections.heading: 5.5. Stretchable Light-Emitting Devices
sections.text:
Stretchable LEDs have attracted lots of attention in recent years because they offer great opportunities for a wide range of practical applications in various fields such as lightings and display,[23,205–209] robotics,[210] and bio-applications.[133,210,211] To date, two approaches have been demonstrated for stretchable LEDs. The first is an interconnect structure that consists of discrete rigid commercial LEDs and stretchable interconnects on soft rubbery polymers[23,128,205,206,209,212] The second strategy is intrinsically stretchable organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) where a stretchable device is fabricated using all elastomeric components.[63,207,208,213–215] 1D nanomaterials served as elastomeric composite electrodes for both strategies.
With the first layout, commercial LEDs are rigid and therefore will not deform with the deformation of rubbery substrates. In this case, 1D nanowires and nanotubes were fabricated as conductive elastomeric interconnects between the LEDs, which undertakes major deformation when the device is stretched. For instance, a printable elastic conductor has been used for stretchable conductive interconnects of OLEDs (Figure 15a). The printable ink consists of SWNTs and an ionic liquid to create a SWNT rubber elastic conductor. The conductivity and stretchability published in this work is over 100 S cm−1 and 100% (Figure 15b). In addition, the display could operate under the strain of 50% with excellent light-emission characteristics (Figure 15c).[23] The conductivity of the printable ink could increase by up to 5710 S cm2 under 0% strain based on hybrid silver–nanotube composites. However, the excellent conductivity of the composite film is significantly decreased with the increasing of strain, which may limit their applications when high strain is required.
In addition, high-aspect-ratio nanowire or nanotube structures could also maintain good transparency, which is favorable as stretchable top and bottom electrodes for OLEDs.[63,207,213–215] For instance, an elastomeric polymer light-emitting device (EPLED) composed of an electroluminescent polymer layer sandwiched between a pair of elastomeric composite electrodes was demonstrated using a Ag NW and rubbery poly(urethane acrylate) (PUA) matrix.[207] Such a composite electrode maintained an excellent transparency of >80% with sheet resistance of 10 Ω sq−1, and exhibited high stretchability of 120%. The OLED based on such electrodes exhibited a maximum luminance of 2000 cd m−2 and a maximum current efficiency of 5.7 cd A−1. Interestingly, it was indicated that the current efficiency increased under strain due to more balanced electron-hole injection (Figure 15e). However, the brightness of the device decreased with higher strains (Figure 15f), which was mainly because of the shift in sheet resistance of the composite electrodes upon stretching. White PLEDs were also fabricated by this group using graphene oxide soldered Ag NW network, which dramatically reduced the inter-nanowire contact

sections.heading: 6. Applications
sections.text: There are numerous applications for 1D nanomaterial-based wearable electronics, including health monitoring, sports tracking, wearable gaming, soft robotics, voice recognition, and heat management. Here, we summarize several key concepts for the construction of 1D nanomaterial-based soft electronics for practical applications.

sections.heading: 6.1. Biomedical Applications
sections.text:
Much attention is focused on wearable diagnostic devices because of their easy implementation, early diagnosis, and long-term monitoring capabilities.[173,216] In the remote medical care system, wearable sensors gather physiological and environmental data from the human body anytime, anywhere. Measured biometric data may include blood pressure,[217] heartbeat,[100] breathing rate,[25] sweat,[156] and glucose,[208] and beyond.[218] Wearable batteries or supercapacitors could be used as power supplies for sensing devices and wireless systems. The measured biometric data could be transmitted wirelessly from wearable sensors to a mobile phone, an access point, or a medical center. For emergency situations, an alarm message could be sent to an emergency service center to provide immediate assistance. After medical treatment, the long-term healthcare of patients could be monitored remotely during the recovery process.[173,216]
Figure 16a shows a single-pixel contact lens display fabricated by integrating an inorganic light-emitting diode (ILED) on a soft eye contact lens with the flexible and stretchable interconnects of the graphene-Ag NW hybrid electrodes.[133] The transparent and stretchable characteristics of the graphene-Ag NW hybrid electrodes provide good electrical interfaces between the rigid ILED and deformable, soft contact lens substrate. Such a device could be operated safely on a live rabbit eye by supplying bias of 4 V (Figure 16b). No abnormal behaviors of the live rabbit were observed, demonstrating excellent biocompatibility of this device.
Figure 16c shows human wrist monitoring using a flexible resistive-type sensor.[100] The wrist pulses could be read out accurately under both normal condition (≈66 beats per minute) and after physical exercise (≈88 beats per minute) as shown in Figure 16d,e. The amplitude, frequency, and waveform of pulses under the two conditions were clearly identified. The results demonstrate that the Au NW-based pressure sensors could serve as a wearable diagnostic device to monitor human’s health in real-time under various conditions.
Biochemical sensors are also key components for diverse healthcare and fitness applications. Figure 16f shows a highly stretchable and printable textile-based potentiometric sensor array for simultaneous multi-ion sweat analysis using variety of fabric materials.[156] PU-based membranes and CNT ink have been coupled to an Ecoflex-containing Ag/AgCl ink and were combined with a solid-contact reference electrode, leading to highly stretchable textile-based potentiometric sensors that transduce their potential response under extreme mechanical stress. The resulting textile-based potentiometric sensors sustain extreme conditions, including large stretching and bending deformations. A calibration curve of each electrode was recorded at 0%, 25%, 50%, 75%, and 100% strains with different concentration of Na+ and K+. Both tests indicated

sections.heading: 6.2. Sports Tracking
sections.text:
Skin wearable strain or pressure sensors can be used for sports tracking by mounting them onto different parts of human body. Figure 17a shows a CNT-based skin-mountable strain sensor attached to the knee of a commercial stocking.[28] The device could easily detect and discriminate various human motions related to the extension and flexion of the knee, including bending, marching, squatting and jumping, and combinations of these (Figure 17b). For example, the complex motion of explosive jumping using a squatting motion could be clearly determined from the initial knee flexing (upward slope), quick knee extension (downward slope), slight flexure from
the landing (second upward slope), and recovery (final downward slope). Skin-attachable sensors are therefore beneficial for the continuous wellness monitoring, human-friendly rehabilitation, wearable gaming, and evaluation of athletes’ sport performances.[24,219]

sections.heading: 6.3. Posture-Driven Gaming
sections.text:
The tracking signals initiated by body movement could be further used and transmission of these signals could be used to realize remote wireless control, which is favorable for wearable posture-driven gaming systems. Such techniques would also be beneficial in performing surgical procedures or delicate and dangerous work that may be out of reach for the human body.[28] For instance, various smart gloves were developed using stretchable, skin-mountable, and wearable strain sensors.[28,65,96,219]
