The strain sensors were attached to the fingers of gloves for the bending angle measurement of finger joints (Figure 18). Specifically, we developed the remote control of a robotic arm using wearable strain sensors.[96] The resistance change of sensors was collected by a chip with a custom written graphical user interface (GUI). The designed chip then transmitted the data wirelessly to a computer. The wireless signals were used to activate the motors in the robot arm. Bending/straightening of fingers was utilized to control the robot for performing different tasks, such as picking up and releasing an object (Figure 18).

sections.heading: 6.4. Voice Recognition
sections.text: Voice recognition represents another key technique for the application of human–machine interfaces and smart robotics. Voice recognition is more challenging compared to human motion detection because the sound vibration pressure (normally <1 Pa) is far lower than pressure of human motion (1 kPa to 10 kPa), which is barely perceived by typical pressure sensors.[158] In this case, ultrasensitive wearable pressure sensors were developed.[18,25,32,100] In 2014, our group designed a Au NW-based pressure sensor to detect acoustic vibrations. The sensor was attached to a sponge and positioned close to a speaker with a fixed spacing from a few to tens of millimeters (Figure 19a). The tiny vibrational forces from both music and repeated sounds could be accurately resolved (Figure 19b,c). Additionally, the reliable current signals accompanyingboth the amplitude and frequency of acoustic vibrations could be detected when the sensor was 30 mm away from the speaker (Figure 19c). Furthermore, a thickness-gradient CNT film was developed for the application of music recognition.[32] The signal of nine basic pitches and the song of “Twinkle Twinkle Little Star” were recorded, and every pitch was distinctly recognized with different amplitude of current changes (Figure 19d). This indicates that the entire vibration damping process was captured, and it would be of importance for recognizing the acoustic vibration information.

sections.heading: 6.5. Heat Management
sections.text:
Heating consumes large amount of energy and is a primary source of greenhouse gas emissions.[220] The mitigation of energy use for heating is critical for solving the global energy
crisis. For the purpose of personal thermal management, 1D nanomaterials have been widely used for the fabrication wearable heaters[22,27,66] and clothing that could reduce heat loss.[220]
A nanowire cloth that could efficiently warm human bodies and save hundreds of watts per person as compared to traditional indoor heaters was reported.[220] The cloth was coated with metallic Ag NWs, reflecting the majority of human body radiation toward the body and greatly enhancing the insulation performance (Figure 20a). The low-emissivity and the low thermal radiation of Ag NW coating makes the Ag NW-cloth appear “cold” in the thermal image (Figure 20b). The weighted average by human body radiation for Ag NW-cloth is 40.8% versus only 1.3% for normal cloth (Figure 20c). The Ag NWcloth could also be activated as a heater by applying a voltage to it. Figure 20d shows the temperature change versus time when a voltage is applied to Ag NW-cloth. A small voltage of 0.9 V can induce a temperature change up to 38°C, which is higher than human body core temperature (37 °C) and skin temperature (33 °C). In addition, a soft and stretchable heating element was demonstrated.[66] Such a wearable heater was lightweight and thin, which allowed conformal contact with the human joints and the skin for effective heat transfer and thermotherapy.[66] The heater was composed of uniformly dispersed Ag NW films sandwiched in a SBS elastomer. The composite film was designed into various patterns to improve the wearability (Figure 20e,f). Because of the high conductivity of Ag NWs, the temperature could be rapidly increased from room temperature to ≈40 °C with only an applied voltage of 1.0 V (Figure 20g). The stable and fast heating property of the resultant wearable heater was also confirmed by the repetitive on–off cycles with a duration of ≈60s under an applied voltage of 0.5 V (Figure 20h).

sections.heading: 6.6. Pressure Mapping
sections.text:
The construction of device matrices that allow for force detection and visualization in a large area is essential for most sensing applications. The fabrication of pressure sensor arrays has been achieved with a different design for pressure/force mapping. Advances in 1D nanomaterials and processing techniques promote the development of large-area active matrices that are integrated with pressure sensing devices. For example, we presented pressure arrays based on Au NWs with simply “dip-and-cut” strategy.[100] Such sensor matrices could map tiny objects such as a metal key with weight of only 6 g. In addition,
Figure 18. 1D nanomaterials based soft electronics for posture-driven gaming. Photograph of a remote wireless controlling demonstration. The motors of robotic arm were controlled by Au NWs strain sensors on a data glove. Left to right: clamp object → lift object up → put object down → release object. an integrated sensor matrix with 10 × 10 pixels was introduced for the demonstration of force distribution based on Ag NW deposited fabrics (Figure 21a).[69] The pressure induced by an iron rob on the electronic fabric was plotted onto a 2D map, as shown in Figure 21b. The color contrast mapping clearly showed that the value of force close to the iron rod was bigger than that on the side position of the electronic fabric. The electronic fabric could also keep its function when it was immobilized on an arbitrary curved surface (Figure 21c,d) or when it was being stretched.
While most of investigations on force mapping have focused on the optimization of pressure sensors interfaced with an electronic readout, user interfaces based on a visualized output was rarely reported. An appropriate approach to solve the problem is the integration of pressure sensing elements with LEDs. A user-interactive e-skin[215] (Figure 21e) that not only spatially mapped the applied pressure but also provided an instantaneous visual response through a built-in active-matrix OLED driven by nanotube-based transistors. The OLED pixels could be turned on locally when the surface was touched, and the intensity of the emitted light quantified the magnitude of the applied pressure (Figure 21f). As a result, objects with different shapes could be visualized with activated OLED pixels when they were laid on the sensing matrices (Figure 21g,h).

sections.heading: 7. Challenges and Perspective
sections.text:
The fabrication of high-performance wearable and soft electronics can be achieved using novel 1D nanomaterials. Such devices enable applications of wearable biomedical monitoring, sports tracking, remote controlling, voice recognition, thermal management, force imaging, and beyond. Despite the progress described in this article, many challenges must be addressed before practical application becomes possible. First, the scalable, low-cost manufacture of wearable electronics based on 1D nanomaterials is critically needed. The top-down approach with roll-to-roll techniques has seen remarkable success for CNT-based electronics due to their compatibility with batch fabrication.[36] However, it is challenging to realize large-scale manufacturing of nanowire-based electronics because of their lab-scale synthesis methods and bottom-up assembly methods, via which it is difficult to achieve the same level of precision, uniformity, and scalability. Recent progress in screenprinting,[96,101,156] spray-coating,[50,142–144] direct writing,[88,96] ink-jet printing,[141] and 3D printing[145] of a variety of nanowires has shown great promise to overcome the current challenge with a much lower cost than top-down micro/nanofabrication.
For the application of stretchable conductors/LEDs, connectors and electrodes are required to sustain large strain while

This is challenging because high optical transparency usually requires a very thin conductive film, which will inevitably lead to cracking or breakage when a strain is applied. Research efforts should be directed towards synthesis of 1D nanomaterials synthesis with higher aspect ratios. Percolation theory predicts that longer and thinner NWs lead to conductors[10,11] with a better balance of conductivity and transmittance. The synthesis of long, thin, and flexible NWs with uniform diameter and good quality could substantially improve the performance of stretchable conductors and LED devices. Additionally, the microstructure and geometrical shape design of

1D nanomaterials electrodes is an effective strategy to further ease the strain to the conductive material itself. However, most conductors are stretchable in one direction. Although some structural designs have already been demonstrated to be biaxial stretchable,[39,221,222] multi-axial stretching ability is needed to design isotropically stretchable conductors.
As for optoelectronic applications, the empty space between 1D nanomaterials does not conduct any current. Such empty “holes” may restrict electron transport efficiency especially in solar cells and LEDs with laminated structures. This challenge could be addressed by introducing a multiscale hybrid nanostructure that combines the high mechanical compliance, electrical conductivity, and optical transparency of small filler materials (CNTs, graphene, ITO) into one system. The high electrical conductivity of 1D nanomaterials (Ag NWs, Cu NWs) can enable efficient multiscale electron transport path.[124,132,133] Thus, larger specific surface area and higher electrical conductivity could be achieved simultaneously.
As for wearable and stretchable force sensors, simultaneous achievement of high compliance and high sensitivity is still a great challenge, especially for personalized healthcare applications in which tiny pressure or strain changes on the surface of human skin (pulse, blood pressure, heartbeat, voice sensing, etc.) need to be captured. Such devices are required to have full compliance to human skin to accurately detect pressure or strain changes.[173] However, materials mismatch at interfaces between low Young-modulus skin and high Young-modulus nanomaterials thin film occur upon deformation, thus resulting in false signals and inaccurate information. Much effort has been devoted recently to overcome these challenges using ultralow Young-modulus conductive materials such as ionic liquid[223–225] and liquid metal[226,227] for the construction of soft electronics. Another major challenge is the packaging of flexible sensors with power, signal processing, communication, and data management units. Most of the current solutions use conventional data acquisition system through rigid wiring and rigid power supplier units with soft sensing devices. Such accessories have poor wearing comfort, which makes it difficult to use them for wearable biomedical monitoring anytime and anywhere. Recent developments in wearable energy harvesting and storage devices are promising for powering wearable sensor systems. Such devices are mainly based on aligned CNTs that have been explored for both planar and fiber-shaped design with improved wearing comfort.[228,229] To date, efforts have been made to directly integrate flexible energy storage and communication modules with flexible sensors.[230–234] However, the integration of all sensor, power, and communication modules in a soft and compact device with high reliability, robustness, compliance, and long-term monitoring capability has not been achieved yet. Further investigations are needed for addressing this challenge.
The main obstacle for stretchable energy storage and conversion devices based on 1D nanomaterials is the low optoelectronic performance. For example, stretchable supercapacitors based on SWCNTs only demonstrated a specific capacitance of ≈50 F g−1 on elastomer substrates.[182] Addition of redox materials can improve the specific capacitance but is detrimental to the electrical conductivity and cyclic stability, especially when subjected to repeated stretching. In order to fabricate high-performance energy devices, it is crucial to develop new
synthetic methods of 1D nanomaterials to accurately control their morphologies and properties. The microstructure of the 1D nanomaterials is also a key factor for the property of the resulting bulk materials including film and fiber. For instance, the aligned CNT materials were found to exhibit much better performance than the randomly dispersed CNT materials.[8] Moreover, alternative energy harvesting devices that can convert energy from body motion, heat, or friction have recently received considerable attention. Such adaptive energy devices can generate and harvest energy from the movement of wearers for the continuous energy supply of wearable sensing system.[235]

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text: In conclusion, we have systematically reviewed significant progress that has been made in recent years in the field of wearable soft electronics based on 1D nanomaterials. A variety of novel materials including carbon nanotubes, metal and metal oxide nanowires, polymer nanowires, and hybrid materials have been categorized and discussed in detail. Because of their unique materials properties, wearable electronic devices are constructed with improved performance, such as effective charge transport through percolation networks of 1D materials system that lead to a high conductivity and high optical transparency with low materials consumption. We also cover several viable methods for constructing wearable soft electronics with 1D nanomaterials. Careful selection of fabrication strategies can lead to rational design of electronic devices with optimum performance. For instance, resistive-type strain sensors require large electrical conductivity changes upon deformation, while stretchable electrodes require both high and constant conductivity when being stretched. Such features could be achieved using specific material synthesis and processing methodologies. Various types of wearable electronic devices are also discussed and summarized. 1D nanomaterials have exhibited applications for almost all required components in wearable electronics such as sensors and energy devices. Seeing recent exciting progresses, we believe that 1D nanomaterials based soft electronics will lead to many real-world applications in the near future; these may include biomedical monitoring, sports tracking, soft robotics, entertainment technology, artificial intelligence, and heat management. The remaining challenges include scalable low-cost materials synthesis and manufacturing, multiscale conformal mechanics with soft human body before and after deformation, ergonomic design of packaging products, and durability under various harsh conditions.

referenceMentions.context: [89] Various synthesis methods were developed to promote the utilization of Au NWs, including chemical reduction,[90,91] electrodeposition,[92] lithography/lift-off processes,[93] and slicing thin Au films.

[89] Various synthesis methods were developed to promote the utilization of Au NWs, including chemical reduction,[90,91] electrodeposition,[92] lithography/lift-off processes,[93] and slicing thin Au films.

[94] However, most of the early reported techniques resulted in the production of polycrystalline or relatively large diameter (45 nm) nanowires with low aspect ratios and rough surfaces.[91] The thick and short nanowires are intrinsically rigid and show poor mechanical/electrical www.
In 2008, the synthesis of ultrathin Au NWs (<5 nm) was developed[90,91,95] by using oleylamine (OA) or combined chemicals as both 1D growth templates and reducing agents (Figure 5a).

Graphene typically shows poor electrical and mechanical stretchability because of structural defects or large interlayer resistance,[136] which restricts its application in soft electronics.
To enhance the conductivity and stretchability, introducing CNTs[137] and metal nanowires[138] have been developed.

Current achievements in stretchable electronics have largely been attributed to advances in stretchable, compliant conductors.[149] Stretchability and conductivity remain two crucial parameters to evaluate the performance of a stretchable conductor.

[150] There are several advantages of piezoelectric sensors including wide frequency response range, high sensitivity to dynamic pressures, and low power consumption (or even no need for power).[163,164] Benefitting from these merits, piezoelectric sensors are widely used in the detection of dynamic pressures such as vibrations of sound and slip.

metadata.abstractText: Electronic devices will evolve from the current rigid systems to flexible systems and ultimately to stretchable electronics, enabling true seamless integration of electronics with biology. The current wearable electronics may be the transition stage to such future electronic system. The development of soft wearable electronic systems for measurement and collection of biometric data provides a plethora of opportunities for artificial intelligence, disease diagnosis, sports tracking, and health monitoring.[1–7] It is encouraging to see a growing number of publications in this exciting area with ≈1400 publications in 2015; this is almost four times the number of publications 5 years ago. Various active materials have been used in soft wearable Electronics will evolve from current rigid electronics to flexible electronics to ultimate soft stretchable electronics. The currently available, rapidly evolving wearable electronics may be a transitional stage to the future stretchable electronics. One-dimensional (1D) nanomaterials are being extensively used for the design of novel wearable conductors, sensors, and energy devices because 1D nanostructures have an intrinsically high-aspect-ratio that enables the construction of conductive percolation network with small amount of material usage while maintaining high optoelectronic performance. Simultaneously, 1D nanostructures have better mechanical elasticity than corresponding bulk materials or sphere-like nanoparticles and this is a key requirement for designing electronic skin materials by circumventing material delamination and/or cracking. Here, recent progress in 1D nanomaterials based on carbon, metal, metal oxides, polymer, and their hybrid structures is reviewed, focusing on the application of soft wearable electronics. In particular, 1D nanomaterial-based stretchable conductors, wearable pressure and strain sensors, wearable energy storage devices, and stretchable light-emitting diode devices are discussed in detail. Representative fabrication methodologies are described and their advantages/disadvantages are compared. Finally, the innovative application of 1D nanomaterial-based sensors/devices in health and wellness, safety, artificial intelligence, entertainment, and early detection of mental disorders is discussed.
